Mit dem Bischofsstab des Benno von Meißen (2006)
Mit Papst Benedikt XVI. am Münchener Marienplatz (2006)

,Friedrich Wetter was born the son of a railwayman family - his father was a locomotive driver. He grew up with the two sisters Hildegard and Hedwig (as Sister Maria Immolata). After graduating from high school in 1948 at Landauer Gymnasium weather studied Catholic theology at the Philosophical-Theological College Sankt Georgen in Frankfurt am Main and at the Pontifical Gregorian University in Rome. There he received on 10 October 1953 by Cardinal Cardinal Clemente Micara ordained priest. In 1956 he was awarded a thesis on the teaching of Benedict XII. from the intensive growth of the divine show to doctor of theology. From 1956 to 1958, Wetter worked as a chaplain in Speyer, where he then worked until 1960 as an assistant and lecturer at the seminary. After that, he was for a short time assistant priest in Glan-Münchweiler, Westphalia, until 1961, he was on leave for habilitation. He continued his academic career first as a lecturer and later as a professor of fundamental theology at Eichstätt University of Applied Sciences. In 1965 he habilitated at the Martin Grabmann Research Institute in Munich with the dogmatist Michael Schmaus with the work The Trinitarian Theory of John Duns Scotus. In 1967 he received a professorship for dogmatics at Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz. After Pope Paul VI. appointed as Bishop of Speyer, he still worked as honorary professor. His episcopal ordination took place on June 29, 1968 in the cathedral at Speyer. Consecrator was his predecessor on the Speyer bishopric, Isidore Markus Emanuel; Co-consecrators were the Mainz Bishop Hermann Volk and the Trier Auxiliary Bishop Alfred Kleinermeilert. After Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger had been appointed as Prefect of the Congregation of the Faith to Rome, Wetter was appointed in 1982 as his successor to Pope John Paul II the 12th Archbishop of Munich and Freising and on May 25, 1985 as cardinal priest with the titular church of Santo Stefano al Monte Celio accepted into the College of Cardinals. In the German Bishops' Conference in 1981, he had taken over the chairmanship of the Faith Commission, this office he held until 2008. [1] Weather had already 2003 shortly before his 75th birthday, as the church law in Can. 401 § 1, the pope offered his resignation, but John Paul II had rejected this for the time being. First Pope Benedict XVI. On February 2, 2007, he accepted the resignation, but at the same time requested that Wetter, as Apostolic Administrator, with all the rights and powers of a diocesan bishop, continue to administer the Archdiocese until a new Archbishop has been appointed. Cardinal Weather complied with this request. [2] The Apostolic Administrator appointment is considered unusual; because usually it is up to the cathedral chapter to elect a diocesan administrator for the duration of the vacancy. With the appointment of the administrator by the Pope, the cathedral chapter was deprived of this opportunity. The measure was attributed to the special relationship of trust between the Pope and the weather. On November 30, 2007, Pope Benedict XVI. the former Bishop of Trier, Reinhard Marx, as Archbishop of Munich and Freising. Weather's term ended on February 2, 2008, when Marx was introduced to his new post under a Pontifical Mass. Wetter is a member of the Board of Trustees at the Jewish Center Munich. [3] He is an honorary member of the Marian Men's Congregation of the Annunciation founded in 1610 at the Civic Hall of Munich. [4] On the occasion of his retirement, the Catholic Academy in Bavaria in 2008 called the named after him Cardinal Weather Prize to life, with the theological dissertation or habilitation thesis are awarded annually. At the Corpus Christi Procession in Munich (2005) With the Bishop's Staff of Benno von Meissen (2006) With Pope Benedict XVI. at the Munich Marienplatz (2006)",https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Wetter,1,Liste_der_Bisch%C3%B6fe_von_Freising_und_der_Erzbisch%C3%B6fe_von_M%C3%BCnchen_und_Freising

125,Reinhard Kardinal Marx,2008,,"Reinhard Marx wuchs als Sohn eines Schlossermeisters im westfälischen Geseke auf. Er legte im Jahre 1972 am Gymnasium Antonianum (dort im Bund Neudeutschland aktiv) in Geseke die Abiturprüfung ab. Er studierte anschließend an der Theologischen Fakultät Paderborn und in Paris katholische Theologie.

Am 2. Juni 1979 empfing er das Sakrament der Priesterweihe durch Erzbischof Johannes Joachim Degenhardt. Seiner zweijährigen Tätigkeit als Vikar in Arolsen schloss sich von 1981 bis 1989 ein Zweitstudium an der Ruhr-Universität Bochum und der Westfälischen Wilhelms-Universität in Münster an. 1988 wurde Marx an der Katholisch-Theologischen Fakultät der Ruhr-Universität Bochum bei dem Fundamentaltheologen Hermann Josef Pottmeyer mit der Arbeit Ist Kirche anders? – Möglichkeiten und Grenzen einer soziologischen Betrachtungsweise zum Dr. theol. promoviert.

1989 wurde er Direktor des Sozialinstituts Kommende Dortmund des Erzbistums Paderborn im Dortmunder Stadtteil Brackel. Während seiner Tätigkeit in der Kommende war Reinhard Marx Subsidiar in der St.-Ewaldi-Gemeinde in Aplerbeck.

1990 wurde er von Kardinal-Großmeister Giuseppe Kardinal Caprio zum Großoffizier des Ritterordens vom Heiligen Grab zu Jerusalem ernannt und durch Franz Kardinal Hengsbach, Großprior der deutschen Statthalterei, investiert. Am 21. Juni 1993 verlieh ihm Papst Johannes Paul II. den Titel „Kaplan Seiner Heiligkeit“.[1] 1996 erfolgte die Berufung zum außerordentlichen Professor für Christliche Gesellschaftslehre an die Theologische Fakultät Paderborn.

Am 23. Juli 1996 ernannte Papst Johannes Paul II. ihn zum Titularbischof von Petina und zum Weihbischof im Erzbistum Paderborn. Die Bischofsweihe spendete ihm Erzbischof Johannes Joachim Degenhardt am 21. September desselben Jahres; Mitkonsekratoren waren die beiden Paderborner Weihbischöfe Hans Leo Drewes und Paul Consbruch. Am 20. Dezember 2001 berief ihn Papst Johannes Paul II. als Nachfolger Hermann Josef Spitals zum 102. Bischof von Trier.[2] Er wurde am 1. April 2002 in sein Amt eingeführt. Sein Bischofsmotto Ubi spiritus domini, ibi libertas („Wo der Geist des Herrn wirkt, da ist Freiheit“) stammt aus 2 Kor 3,17 EU. Marx wurde 1999 Vorsitzender der Deutschen Kommission Justitia et Pax („Gerechtigkeit und Frieden“), die von der Deutschen Bischofskonferenz und dem Zentralkomitee der deutschen Katholiken getragen wird. In diesem Amt wurde er 2004 für weitere fünf Jahre bestätigt. Die Deutsche Bischofskonferenz wählte ihn auf der Herbst-Vollversammlung 2004 zum Vorsitzenden ihrer Kommission für gesellschaftliche und soziale Fragen. In Nachfolge von Anton Schlembach wurde Marx 2006 Großprior der Deutschen Statthalterei des Ritterordens vom Heiligen Grab zu Jerusalem.[3]

Papst Benedikt XVI. ernannte ihn am 30. November 2007 zum Erzbischof von München und Freising.[4] Er ist kraft dieses Amts zugleich Vorsitzender der Freisinger Bischofskonferenz. Am 29. Juni 2008 empfing Marx als Metropolit der Kirchenprovinz München und Freising im Petersdom zu Rom das Pallium. Als Nachfolger des Eichstätter Bischofs Gregor Maria Hanke wurde er am 1. Februar 2010 zum Großkanzler der Katholischen Universität Eichstätt-Ingolstadt ernannt; das Amt übernahm er im Oktober 2010.[5][6]
Im Konsistorium vom 20. November 2010 nahm Papst Benedikt XVI. Bischof Marx als

Kardinalpriester mit der Titelkirche San Corbiniano in das Kardinalskollegium auf.[7][8] Bis zur Kreierung Rainer Maria Woelkis im Februar 2012 war Kardinal Marx jüngstes Mitglied des Kardinalskollegiums.

Papst Franziskus berief Marx im April 2013 als ein Mitglied des Kardinalsrates, der den Papst bei der Leitung der Weltkirche beraten und im Hinblick auf eine Reform der Kurie Änderungen der apostolischen Konstitution Pastor Bonus, die die Organisation der Kurie regelt, vorbereiten soll.[9][10]

Am 12. März 2014 wurde Marx bei der Frühjahrsvollversammlung in Münster zum Vorsitzenden der Deutschen Bischofskonferenz gewählt.[8] Die Amtszeit beträgt sechs Jahre.[11] Innerhalb der Bischofskonferenz ist Marx Mitglied der Kommission für gesellschaftliche und soziale Fragen.[12]

Von März 2012 bis März 2018 war er Präsident der Kommission der Bischofskonferenzen der Europäischen Gemeinschaft (COMECE).[13][14] In diesem Amt wurde er im März 2015 für eine dreijährige Amtszeit bestätigt.[15] Diesem Gremium gehört er seit März 2006 als Delegierter der Deutschen Bischofskonferenz an und hatte seit 20. März 2009 das Amt eines Vizepräsidenten der COMECE inne. Das Amt des Vorsitzenden ist auf zwei Amtszeiten begrenzt.[16] 2018 folgte ihm der Essener Bischof Franz-Josef Overbeck als Delegierter nach[17] neuer Vorsitzender ist seither der Erzbischof von Luxemburg Jean-Claude Hollerich S.J.[18]","Reinhard Marx grew up as the son of a master locksmith in Westphalian Geseke. He graduated in 1972 from the Gymnasium Antonianum (there in the Union of New Germany active) in Geseke from the Abitur exam. He then studied Catholic theology at the Faculty of Theology Paderborn and in Paris. On June 2, 1979, he received the sacrament of Holy Orders by Archbishop Johannes Joachim Degenhardt. During his two years as a vicar in Arolsen, he attended a second degree course at the Ruhr-Universität Bochum and the Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität in Münster from 1981 to 1989. In 1988, Marx at the Catholic Theological Faculty of the Ruhr University Bochum at the fundamental theologian Hermann Josef Pottmeyer with the work Is church different? - Possibilities and Limitations of a Sociological View of Dr. Ing. theol. PhD. In 1989 he became director of the Social Institute Kommende Dortmund of the Archdiocese of Paderborn in Dortmund Brackel. During his work in the coming Reinhard Marx Subsidiar was in the St. Ewaldi community in Aplerbeck. In 1990 he was appointed Cardinal Grand Master Giuseppe Cardinal Caprio to the Grand Officer of the Order of the Holy Sepulcher of Jerusalem and invested by Franz Cardinal Hengsbach, Grand Prior of the German Lieutenancy. On June 21, 1993, Pope John Paul II awarded him the title "Chaplain of His Holiness." [1] In 1996 he was appointed Associate Professor of Christian Social Studies at the Faculty of Theology in Paderborn. On July 23, 1996, Pope John Paul II appointed him Titular Bishop of Petina and Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of Paderborn. Archbishop Johannes Joachim Degenhardt gave him episcopal consecration on 21 September of the same year; Co-consecrators were the two Paderborn auxiliary bishops Hans Leo Drewes and Paul Consbruch. On December 20, 2001, Pope John Paul II appointed him as the successor of Hermann Josef Hospital for 102nd Bishop of Trier. He was inducted into office on April 1, 2002. His episcopal motto Ubi spiritus domini, ibi libertas ("Where the Spirit of the Lord works, there is freedom") comes from 2 Cor 3:17 EU. In 1999, Marx became chairman of the German Commission Justitia et Pax ("Justice and Peace"), which is supported by the German Bishops' Conference and the Central Committee of German Catholics. In this office he was confirmed in 2004 for another five years. The German Bishops' Conference elected him Chair of its Commission on Social and Social Issues at the 2004 Autumn Assembly. In succession to Anton Schlembach Marx was in 2006 Grand Prior of the German Lieutenancy of the Order of the Holy Sepulcher of Jerusalem. Pope Benedict XVI. appointed him on 30 November 2007 Archbishop of Munich and Freising. He is also the chairman of the Freising Bishops' Conference. On June 29, 2008, Marx received the pallium as Metropolitan of the ecclesiastical province of Munich and Freising in St. Peter's Basilica in Rome. As successor of the Eichstätter bishop Gregory Maria Hanke he was appointed on February 1, 2010 the Grand Chancellor of the Catholic University of Eichstätt-Ingolstadt; the office he took over in October 2010. [5] In the consistory of 20 November 2010, Pope Benedict XVI. Bishop Marx as cardinal priest with the titular church of San Corbiniano in the College of Cardinals. [7] [8] Until the creation of Rainer Maria Woelkis in February 2012, Cardinal Marx was the youngest member of the College of Cardinals. Pope Francis called Marx in April 2013 as a member of the Cardinal Council, who advised the Pope in the direction of the universal Church and with a view to a reform of the Curia to prepare changes to the apostolic constitution Pastor Bonus, which governs the organization of the Curia. [9] [10] On March 12, 2014, Marx was elected chairman of the German Bishops' Conference at the spring assembly in Münster. [8] The term of office is six years. [11] Within the Episcopal Conference, Marx is a member of the Commission for Social and Social Issues. [12] From March 2012 to March 2018 he was President of the Commission of the Episcopal Conferences of the European Community (COMECE). [13] [14] In this office he was confirmed in March 2015 for a three-year term. He has been a member of this committee since March 2006 as a delegate of the German Bishops' Conference and since 20 March 2009 he has held the office of Vice President of COMECE. The post of chairman is limited to two terms. [16] In 2018, the Essen Bishop Franz-Josef Overbeck followed him as a delegate to [17] new chairman since then is the Archbishop of Luxembourg Jean-Claude Hollerich SJ",https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinhard_Marx,1,Liste_der_Bisch%C3%B6fe_von_Freising_und_der_Erzbisch%C3%B6fe_von_M%C3%BCnchen_und_Freising
126,"Leo Nowak

,8. Juli 1994,17. März 2004,Nach einer kaufmännischen Ausbildung und einem zweijährigen Studium an der Fachschule für Industrie und Handel entschied sich Nowak 1950 für einen geistlichen Werdegang. Er nahm ein Theologie- und Philosophiestudium an der Universität Paderborn und am Priesterseminar Erfurt auf. Am 10. Mai 1956 wurde er in Magdeburg vom Bischöflichen Kommissarius im Bischöflichen Amt Magdeburg, Friedrich Maria Rintelen, zum Priester geweiht. Anschließend wirkt er von 1956 bis 1958 als Vikar an St. Johannes Baptist (Seehausen), danach in Großkorbetha, Lützen, Merseburg, Ziesar, und von 1967 bis 1975 an St. Anna (Stendal).[1] 1975 wurde ihm von Bischof Johannes Braun die Leitung des Seelsorgeamtes übertragen.

Am 12. Februar 1990 ernannte Papst Johannes Paul II. Leo Nowak zum Titularbischof von Cissa und zum Apostolischen Administrator in Magdeburg. Die Bischofsweihe spendete ihm am 24. März 1990 in Magdeburg sein Amtsvorgänger Johannes Braun. Mitkonsekratoren waren der Erzbischof von Paderborn und spätere Kardinal Johannes Joachim Degenhardt und der Apostolische Administrator von Schwerin, Theodor Hubrich. Nowaks Wahlspruch lautet Instaurare omnia in Christo („Alles in Christus erneuern“).

Ab 1821 bildete das heutige Bistum den Ostteil des Erzbistums Paderborn. Da eine Verwaltung des in der DDR liegenden Gebietes jedoch von Paderborn aus nicht möglich war, wurde dort  1973 ein Bischöfliches Amt errichtet. Dieses gehörte zwar offiziell zum Erzbistum Paderborn und der Apostolische Administrator war dementsprechend auch nur als Weihbischof dort tätig, doch entwickelte es sich faktisch zu einem eigenständigen Bistum. Der (Weih-)Bischof/Administrator war Mitglied der Berliner Bischofskonferenz.

Das heutige Bistum Magdeburg wurde mit der Apostolischen Konstitution Cum gaudio am 27. Juni 1994 vom Erzbistum Paderborn abgetrennt und am 8. Juli 1994 zu einem eigenständigen Bistum mit Leopold Nowak als erstem Bischof erhoben. Dessen Amtszeit endete am 17. März 2004, nachdem Papst Johannes Paul II. das Rücktrittsgesuch angenommen hatte, zu dem jeder Bischof der römisch-katholischen Kirche laut Kirchenrecht verpflichtet ist, wenn er sein 75. Lebensjahr erreicht.

Weihbischof Gerhard Feige, der während der Sedisvakanz die Geschicke des Bistums als Diözesanadministrator leitete, wurde am 23. Februar 2005 vom Papst zum Nachfolger ernannt und am 16. April 2005 in sein Amt eingeführt.
Am 10. Mai 2006 feierte Leo Nowak in der Kathedrale St. Sebastian zu Magdeburg sein Goldenes Priesterjubiläum. Mit ihm feierten vier weitere Goldjubilare des Bistums den Festgottesdienst.

,After a business education and a two-year study at the College of Industry and Commerce Nowak decided in 1950 for a spiritual career. He studied theology and philosophy at the University of Paderborn and at the seminary in Erfurt. On May 10, 1956, he was ordained priest in Magdeburg by the Episcopal Commissioner in the Episcopal Office of Magdeburg, Friedrich Maria Rintelen. He then worked from 1956 to 1958 as a vicar at St. John Baptist (Seehausen), then in Großkorbetha, Lützen, Merseburg, Ziesar, and from 1967 to 1975 at St. Anna (Stendal). In 1975, Bishop Johannes Braun entrusted him with the direction of the pastoral service. On February 12, 1990, Pope John Paul II appointed Leo Nowak Titular Bishop of Cissa and Apostolic Administrator in Magdeburg. The episcopal consecration donated him on March 24, 1990 in Magdeburg his predecessor Johannes Braun. Co-consecrators were the Archbishop of Paderborn and later Cardinal Johannes Joachim Degenhardt and the Apostolic Administrator of Schwerin, Theodor Hubrich. Nowak's motto is Instaurare omnia in Christ ("Renewing All in Christ"). From 1821, today's diocese formed the eastern part of the Archdiocese of Paderborn. However, since an administration of the area lying in the GDR was not possible from Paderborn, a bishopric office was established there in 1973. Although this officially belonged to the Archbishopric of Paderborn and the apostolic administrator was therefore only active as a suffragan bishop there, but it actually developed into an independent diocese. The (bishop) bishop / administrator was a member of the Berlin Bishops' Conference. The current Diocese of Magdeburg was separated with the Apostolic Constitution Cum gaudio on 27 June 1994 by the Archbishopric Paderborn and raised on 8 July 1994 to an independent diocese with Leopold Nowak as the first bishop. His term ended on March 17, 2004, after Pope John Paul II had accepted the resignation to which every bishop of the Roman Catholic Church is required by law to reach the age of 75. Auxiliary Bishop Gerhard Feige, who led the fate of the diocese as diocesan administrator during the vacations, was appointed by the Pope on 23 February 2005 and was appointed to his office on 16 April 2005. On May 10, 2006, Leo Nowak celebrated his Golden Jubilee in the Cathedral of St. Sebastian in Magdeburg. With him celebrated four other gold jubilees of the diocese, the festival service.",https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_Nowak,0,Liste_der_Erzbisch%C3%B6fe_und_Bisch%C3%B6fe_von_Magdeburg
127,"Gerhard Feige
,23. Februar 2005,

,Gerhard Feige studierte nach seinem Abitur an der August-Hermann-Francke-Schule in Halle Katholische Theologie in Erfurt. Am 1. April 1978 empfing er in Magdeburg von Bischof Johannes Braun die Priesterweihe.

Als Vikar wirkte er in Salzwedel und Magdeburg. Anschließend arbeitete er von 1982 am Philosophisch-Theologischen Studium – heute Katholisch-Theologische Fakultät der Universität Erfurt – als Assistent. Nach seiner Promotion zum Doktor der Theologie 1988 und einem anschließenden einjährigen Studienaufenthalt in Rom war er Dozent für Alte Kirchengeschichte, Patrologie und Ökumenische Theologie in Erfurt. 1994 erfolgte seine Berufung zum Professor für Alte Kirchengeschichte, Patrologie und Ostkirchenkunde.

Am 19. Juli 1999 ernannte Papst Johannes Paul II. Gerhard Feige zum Weihbischof in Magdeburg und Titularbischof von Tisedi. Gerhard Feige empfing die Bischofsweihe am 11. September 1999 von Bischof Leo Nowak in der Magdeburger Kathedrale Sankt Sebastian. Als Mitkonsekratoren assistierten dabei die Bischöfe Joachim Wanke von Erfurt und Paul-Werner Scheele von Würzburg. Sein Wahlspruch lautet: Vigilate et orate („Wachet und betet“) und entstammt dem Matthäusevangelium (Mt 26,41 EU).

Nachdem am 17. März 2004 der Rücktritt des Magdeburger Bischofs Leo Nowak aus Altersgründen vom Papst angenommen wurde, wählte das Magdeburger Kathedralkapitel Feige zum Diözesanadministrator für die Zeit der Sedisvakanz.

Am 23. Februar 2005 ernannte ihn Papst Johannes Paul II. zum Nachfolger von Leo Nowak als Diözesanbischof. Die Amtseinführung erfolgte am 16. April 2005 in seiner Bischofskirche Sankt Sebastian in Magdeburg durch den Apostolischen Nuntius, Erzbischof Erwin Josef Ender, und den Metropoliten der Kirchenprovinz Paderborn, Erzbischof Hans-Josef Becker.

Als besonderes Anliegen des Bischofs gilt die Ökumene und besonders die Beziehung zur Orthodoxie mit starkem persönlichen Interesse für die unierten Kirchen. Bereits 1983 erhielt er die Erlaubnis, Gottesdienste auch im byzantinischen Ritus zu feiern (vgl. Biritualismus). Seit 1993 gehört er zur Gemeinsamen Kommission der Griechisch-Orthodoxen Metropolie von Deutschland und der römisch-katholischen Kirche in Deutschland. Noch zu Zeiten als Professor führten ihn regelmäßige Seminarreisen mit Studenten nach Lemberg (Lwiw) in der Ukraine. Siehe hierzu auch bei Kardinal Ljubomyr Husar, Großerzbischof der mit Rom unierten griechisch-katholischen Kirche.

1992 ernannte die Deutsche Bischofskonferenz Feige zu ihrem Delegierten in der Arbeitsgemeinschaft Christlicher Kirchen in Deutschland. Außerdem ist Bischof Feige Mitglied des Ökumenisch-Theologischen Arbeitskreises in Ostdeutschland. Feige ist seit September 2012 neuer Vorsitzender der Ökumenekommission der Deutschen Bischofskonferenz. Er tritt damit die Nachfolge des zum Präfekten der Glaubenskongregation berufenen Erzbischofs Gerhard Ludwig Müller an und wurde bei der Herbstvollversammlung der Bischofskonferenz 2016 in dem Amt bestätigt.[1]

Am 22. Juli 2014 wurde er von Papst Franziskus zum Mitglied des Päpstlichen Rates zur Förderung der Einheit der Christen berufen.[2]","Gerhard Feige studied after his graduation at the August Hermann Francke school in Halle Catholic theology in Erfurt. On April 1, 1978, he received in Magdeburg by Bishop John Brown ordained priest. As a vicar he worked in Salzwedel and Magdeburg. He then worked from 1982 on the Philosophical-Theological Studies - today Catholic Theological Faculty of the University of Erfurt - as an assistant. After his doctorate in theology in 1988 and a subsequent one-year study visit to Rome, he was a lecturer in Ancient Church History, Patrology and Ecumenical Theology in Erfurt. In 1994 he was appointed Professor of Ancient Church History, Patrology and Eastern Church Studies. On 19 July 1999, Pope John Paul II appointed Gerhard Feige Auxiliary Bishop in Magdeburg and Titular Bishop of Tisedi. Gerhard Feige received the episcopal consecration on September 11, 1999 by Bishop Leo Nowak in the Magdeburg Cathedral of St. Sebastian. The co-consecrators were assisted by the bishops Joachim Wanke of Erfurt and Paul-Werner Scheele of Würzburg. His motto is Vigilate et orate ("Watch and Worship") and comes from the Gospel of Matthew (Mt 26:41 EU). After the resignation of the Magdeburg Bishop Leo Nowak was accepted by the Pope on 17 March 2004 for reasons of age, the Magdeburg Cathedral Chapter chose Feige as diocesan administrator for the time of the Sedis vacancy. On February 23, 2005, Pope John Paul II appointed him successor to Leo Nowak as diocesan bishop. The inauguration took place on April 16, 2005 in his episcopal church of St. Sebastian in Magdeburg by the Apostolic Nuncio, Archbishop Erwin Josef Ender, and the Metropolitan of the Church Province of Paderborn, Archbishop Hans-Josef Becker. The special concern of the bishop is ecumenism and especially the relationship to Orthodoxy with strong personal interest for the uniate churches. Already in 1983 he received permission to worship in the Byzantine rite (see Biritualism). Since 1993 he belongs to the Joint Commission of the Greek Orthodox Metropolitan of Germany and the Roman Catholic Church in Germany. Even during his time as a professor, he regularly took seminar trips with students to Lviv in Ukraine. See also Cardinal Ljubomyr Hussar, Major Archbishop of the Greek-Catholic Church united with Rome. In 1992, the German Bishops' Conference appointed Feige to be its delegate to the Association of Christian Churches in Germany. In addition, Bishop Feige is a member of the Ecumenical Theological Working Group in East Germany. Feige has been the new chairman of the Ecumenical Commission of the German Bishops' Conference since September 2012. He succeeds the Archbishop Gerhard Ludwig Müller, who was appointed Prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, and was re-elected to the office of the Bishops Conference in autumn 2016. [1] On July 22, 2014, he was appointed by Pope Francis as a member of the Pontifical Council for Promoting Christian Unity. [2]",https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerhard_Feige,0,Liste_der_Erzbisch%C3%B6fe_und_Bisch%C3%B6fe_von_Magdeburg

130,"Ludwig von Braunschweig-Lüneburg

,1324,1346,,Gerhard Feige studied after his graduation at the August Hermann Francke school in Halle Catholic theology in Erfurt. On April 1, 1978, he received in Magdeburg by Bishop John Brown ordained priest. As a vicar he worked in Salzwedel and Magdeburg. He then worked from 1982 on the Philosophical-Theological Studies - today Catholic Theological Faculty of the University of Erfurt - as an assistant. After his doctorate in theology in 1988 and a subsequent one-year study visit to Rome, he was a lecturer in Ancient Church History, Patrology and Ecumenical Theology in Erfurt. In 1994 he was appointed Professor of Ancient Church History, Patrology and Eastern Church Studies. On 19 July 1999, Pope John Paul II appointed Gerhard Feige Auxiliary Bishop in Magdeburg and Titular Bishop of Tisedi. Gerhard Feige received the episcopal consecration on September 11, 1999 by Bishop Leo Nowak in the Magdeburg Cathedral of St. Sebastian. The co-consecrators were assisted by the bishops Joachim Wanke of Erfurt and Paul-Werner Scheele of Würzburg. His motto is Vigilate et orate ("Watch and Worship") and comes from the Gospel of Matthew (Mt 26:41 EU). After the resignation of the Magdeburg Bishop Leo Nowak was accepted by the Pope on 17 March 2004 for reasons of age, the Magdeburg Cathedral Chapter chose Feige as diocesan administrator for the time of the Sedis vacancy. On February 23, 2005, Pope John Paul II appointed him successor to Leo Nowak as diocesan bishop. The inauguration took place on April 16, 2005 in his episcopal church of St. Sebastian in Magdeburg by the Apostolic Nuncio, Archbishop Erwin Josef Ender, and the Metropolitan of the Church Province of Paderborn, Archbishop Hans-Josef Becker. The special concern of the bishop is ecumenism and especially the relationship to Orthodoxy with strong personal interest for the uniate churches. Already in 1983 he received permission to worship in the Byzantine rite (see Biritualism). Since 1993 he belongs to the Joint Commission of the Greek Orthodox Metropolitan of Germany and the Roman Catholic Church in Germany. Even during his time as a professor, he regularly took seminar trips with students to Lviv in Ukraine. See also Cardinal Ljubomyr Hussar, Major Archbishop of the Greek-Catholic Church united with Rome. In 1992, the German Bishops' Conference appointed Feige to be its delegate to the Association of Christian Churches in Germany. In addition, Bishop Feige is a member of the Ecumenical Theological Working Group in East Germany. Feige has been the new chairman of the Ecumenical Commission of the German Bishops' Conference since September 2012. He succeeds the Archbishop Gerhard Ludwig Müller, who was appointed Prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, and was re-elected to the office of the Bishops Conference in autumn 2016. [1] On July 22, 2014, he was appointed by Pope Francis as a member of the Pontifical Council for Promoting Christian Unity. [2]",https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datei:Ludwig_von_Braunschweig-L%C3%BCneburg.jpg,2,Liste_der_Bisch%C3%B6fe_von_Minden

142,"Heinrich von Sachsen-Lauenburg, auch Heinrich III. von Bremen","
","Fürstbischof Heinrich IV. stammte aus dem Hause Sachsen-Lauenburg. Er war der Sohn des zum Protestantismus übergetretenen Herzogs Franz I. von Sachsen-Lauenburg (1543–1581) und von Sibylle von Sachsen. Mit zehn Jahren bereits erhielt er die Anwartschaft auf eine Domherrenstelle in Köln. Heinrich studierte zunächst an der dortigen Universität, insbesondere beim Juraprofessor Dr. Betzdorf, der sein Hauswirt in Köln war und sein Mentor wurde. Seine Ausbildung und sein späteres Handeln war vor allem durch Betzdorf protestantisch geprägt.

Mehr und mehr traten die Stände in Nordwestdeutschland zum protestantischen Glauben über. 1566 wählte das protestantisch dominierte Domkapitel des Erzbistums Bremen Heinrich zum Erzbischof (Heinrich III.), der als weltliches Oberhaupt nur über das Erzstift Bremen verfügte. Papst Pius V. verweigerte dem protestantischen Erzbischof Heinrich III. die päpstliche Konfirmation, da die katholische Kirche das Bischofsamt nicht anerkannte. Der Nuntius in Köln gab Ende 1573 ein Protokoll wieder, in dem er die kanonischen Voraussetzungen für die Bischofswahl positiv bewerten ließ. Heinrich wurde 1574 auch vom Domkapitel im Fürstbistum Osnabrück zum Fürstbischof gewählt (Heinrich II.). Für Rom war aber eine Anerkennung der Bischofswahlen nicht akzeptabel. Er war somit aus katholischer Sicht lediglich Administrator des Erzbistums Bremen und des Bistums Osnabrück. Im Fürstbistum Münster misslang sein Vorhaben knapp.

Bemühungen um Anerkennung Heinrichs durch Rom waren allerdings vorgeschoben. Zunächst heimlich heiratete er am 25. Oktober 1575 auf der Burg Hagen in Hagen im Bremischen Anna Betzdorf, alias von Broich. Sie war die leibliche Tochter seines Kölner Mentors Betzdorf. Als Begründung ließ er in das Traubuch eintragen, er besitze nicht die Gabe der Keuschheit. Am 14. Oktober 1577 wurde Heinrich auch zum Bischof von Paderborn ausgerufen (Heinrich IV.). Auch hier wurde die päpstliche Konfirmation verweigert. 1578 zog Heinrich demonstrativ und feierlich mit seiner Ehefrau in das protestantische Paderborn ein.
Heinrich hat in einem Doppelspiel stets die römisch-katholischen Formalien für die Bischofsweihe beeidigt, gleichzeitig aber niemals ein katholischer Bischof sein wollen.

Zu Palmsonntag 1585 stürzte der Fürstbischof von Bremen, Osnabrück und Paderborn nach einem evangelischen Gottesdienst in Bremervörde so unglücklich von seinem Pferde, dass er kurz darauf starb. Während in Bremen die Reformation ihren Fortgang nahm, setzte sich mit Heinrichs unerwartetem Tode insbesondere im Fürstbistum Paderborn die Gegenreformation durch.

,Prince-Bishop Henry IV came from the House of Saxony-Lauenburg. He was the son of the converted to Protestantism Duke Francis I of Saxony-Lauenburg (1543-1581) and Sibyl of Saxony. At the age of ten he already received the entitlement to a cathedral office in Cologne. Heinrich first studied at the local university, in particular at law professor Dr. med. Betzdorf, who was his landlord in Cologne and became his mentor. His education and his later actions were mainly Protestant influenced by Betzdorf. More and more the estates in northwestern Germany became Protestant. In 1566, the Protestant-dominated cathedral chapter of the Archbishopric of Bremen chose Heinrich as archbishop (Henry III), who, as a secular head, had only the archbishopric of Bremen. Pope Pius V. refused the Protestant Archbishop Henry III. the papal confirmation, since the Catholic Church did not recognize the episcopate. At the end of 1573, the nuncio in Cologne re-enacted a protocol in which he positively assessed the canonical requirements for the election of the bishop. Henry was elected prince-bishop in 1574 by the cathedral chapter of the Prince-Bishopric of Osnabrück (Henry II). For Rome, however, recognition of the bishop's election was unacceptable. He was thus from a Catholic perspective, only administrator of the Archdiocese of Bremen and the diocese of Osnabrück. In the prince bishopric of Münster, his project failed scarce. Efforts to recognize Henry by Rome, however, were advanced. First, he secretly married on October 25, 1575 at the castle Hagen in Hagen in Bremen Anna Betzdorf, alias of Broich. She was the biological daughter of his Cologne mentor Betzdorf. As a reason, he wrote in the Traubuch that he did not have the gift of chastity. On October 14, 1577 Heinrich was also proclaimed bishop of Paderborn (Henry IV). Again, the papal confirmation was denied. In 1578, Heinrich demonstratively and solemnly moved into Protestant Paderborn with his wife. In a double game, Heinrich always sworn the Roman Catholic form for bishop consecration, but never wanted to be a Catholic bishop. On Palm Sunday 1585, the Prince-Bishop of Bremen, Osnabrück and Paderborn, after an evangelical service in Bremervörde, fell so unhappily from his horse that he died shortly thereafter. While the Reformation continued in Bremen, the Counter-Reformation prevailed with Henry's unexpected death, especially in the Principality of Paderborn.",https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinrich_von_Sachsen-Lauenburg,0,Liste_der_Bisch%C3%B6fe_von_Osnabr%C3%BCck
143,"Meinwerk

,1009,1036,,Prince-Bishop Henry IV came from the House of Saxony-Lauenburg. He was the son of the converted to Protestantism Duke Francis I of Saxony-Lauenburg (1543-1581) and Sibyl of Saxony. At the age of ten he already received the entitlement to a cathedral office in Cologne. Heinrich first studied at the local university, in particular at law professor Dr. med. Betzdorf, who was his landlord in Cologne and became his mentor. His education and his later actions were mainly Protestant influenced by Betzdorf. More and more the estates in northwestern Germany became Protestant. In 1566, the Protestant-dominated cathedral chapter of the Archbishopric of Bremen chose Heinrich as archbishop (Henry III), who, as a secular head, had only the archbishopric of Bremen. Pope Pius V. refused the Protestant Archbishop Henry III. the papal confirmation, since the Catholic Church did not recognize the episcopate. At the end of 1573, the nuncio in Cologne re-enacted a protocol in which he positively assessed the canonical requirements for the election of the bishop. Henry was elected prince-bishop in 1574 by the cathedral chapter of the Prince-Bishopric of Osnabrück (Henry II). For Rome, however, recognition of the bishop's election was unacceptable. He was thus from a Catholic perspective, only administrator of the Archdiocese of Bremen and the diocese of Osnabrück. In the prince bishopric of Münster, his project failed scarce. Efforts to recognize Henry by Rome, however, were advanced. First, he secretly married on October 25, 1575 at the castle Hagen in Hagen in Bremen Anna Betzdorf, alias of Broich. She was the biological daughter of his Cologne mentor Betzdorf. As a reason, he wrote in the Traubuch that he did not have the gift of chastity. On October 14, 1577 Heinrich was also proclaimed bishop of Paderborn (Henry IV). Again, the papal confirmation was denied. In 1578, Heinrich demonstratively and solemnly moved into Protestant Paderborn with his wife. In a double game, Heinrich always sworn the Roman Catholic form for bishop consecration, but never wanted to be a Catholic bishop. On Palm Sunday 1585, the Prince-Bishop of Bremen, Osnabrück and Paderborn, after an evangelical service in Bremervörde, fell so unhappily from his horse that he died shortly thereafter. While the Reformation continued in Bremen, the Counter-Reformation prevailed with Henry's unexpected death, especially in the Principality of Paderborn.",https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datei:FBPB_30_Bischof_Meinwerk_auf_Tragaltar_Helmarshausen_1100.jpg,0,Liste_der_Bisch%C3%B6fe_und_Erzbisch%C3%B6fe_von_Paderborn
144,"Heinrich II. von Werl

,1084,1127,,Prince-Bishop Henry IV came from the House of Saxony-Lauenburg. He was the son of the converted to Protestantism Duke Francis I of Saxony-Lauenburg (1543-1581) and Sibyl of Saxony. At the age of ten he already received the entitlement to a cathedral office in Cologne. Heinrich first studied at the local university, in particular at law professor Dr. med. Betzdorf, who was his landlord in Cologne and became his mentor. His education and his later actions were mainly Protestant influenced by Betzdorf. More and more the estates in northwestern Germany became Protestant. In 1566, the Protestant-dominated cathedral chapter of the Archbishopric of Bremen chose Heinrich as archbishop (Henry III), who, as a secular head, had only the archbishopric of Bremen. Pope Pius V. refused the Protestant Archbishop Henry III. the papal confirmation, since the Catholic Church did not recognize the episcopate. At the end of 1573, the nuncio in Cologne re-enacted a protocol in which he positively assessed the canonical requirements for the election of the bishop. Henry was elected prince-bishop in 1574 by the cathedral chapter of the Prince-Bishopric of Osnabrück (Henry II). For Rome, however, recognition of the bishop's election was unacceptable. He was thus from a Catholic perspective, only administrator of the Archdiocese of Bremen and the diocese of Osnabrück. In the prince bishopric of Münster, his project failed scarce. Efforts to recognize Henry by Rome, however, were advanced. First, he secretly married on October 25, 1575 at the castle Hagen in Hagen in Bremen Anna Betzdorf, alias of Broich. She was the biological daughter of his Cologne mentor Betzdorf. As a reason, he wrote in the Traubuch that he did not have the gift of chastity. On October 14, 1577 Heinrich was also proclaimed bishop of Paderborn (Henry IV). Again, the papal confirmation was denied. In 1578, Heinrich demonstratively and solemnly moved into Protestant Paderborn with his wife. In a double game, Heinrich always sworn the Roman Catholic form for bishop consecration, but never wanted to be a Catholic bishop. On Palm Sunday 1585, the Prince-Bishop of Bremen, Osnabrück and Paderborn, after an evangelical service in Bremervörde, fell so unhappily from his horse that he died shortly thereafter. While the Reformation continued in Bremen, the Counter-Reformation prevailed with Henry's unexpected death, especially in the Principality of Paderborn.",https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datei:Heinrichwerl.jpg,0,Liste_der_Bisch%C3%B6fe_und_Erzbisch%C3%B6fe_von_Paderborn
